title: Why Pythagorean scales can't be perfect: cycles of 5ths and 4ths | Maths and Music | N J Wildberger

media:group.media:title: Why Pythagorean scales can't be perfect: cycles of 5ths and 4ths | Maths and Music | N J Wildberger
media:group.media:description:
We look at the relationships between octaves (2:1), perfect fifths (3:2) and perfect fourths (4:3) as the Pythagoreans envisioned musical intervals, and demonstrate on the piano why there is a fundamental mathematical discrepancy here. Arithmetically it comes down to the fact that a power of three cannot equal a power of two. This investigation also allows us to meet two important sequences of notes: the cycle of fifths and the cycle of fourths.

This is one of a series of videos on the interplay between mathematics and music that we will see cuts both ways: each subject reveals structure and truths about the other.

I also want to introduce you to my very modest TikTok channel: 

www.tiktok.com/@njwildberger

where I am posting some on-the-spot piano improvisations, and the occasional classical piece, some of them not by J. S. Bach.

My research papers can be found at my Research Gate page, at https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Norman_Wildberger

My blog is at http://njwildberger.com/, where I will discuss lots of foundational issues, along with other things.

Online courses will be developed at openlearning.com. The first one, already underway is Algebraic Calculus One at https://www.openlearning.com/courses/algebraic-calculus-one/ Please join us for an exciting new approach to one of mathematics' most important subjects!
